statement.tex: \text{Differentiate the following } \\ \quad \sin \left(\tan^{-1} e^{-x}\right) \\ \text{with respect to x.}\\
\\ \text{If }\sin (\tan^{-1} (e^{-x})) = f(\, g(\, h(x)\,)\,), \\ \text{then what are f,g and h?}

options.tex: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline f(x) & g(x) & h(x) \\ \hline \sin x & \tan^{-1} x & e^{-x} \\ \hline \end{tabular}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline f(x) & g(x) & h(x) \\ \hline \tan^{-1} x & e^{-x} & \sin x \\ \hline \end{tabular}

reason.tex: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline f(x) & g(x) & h(x) & f(\,g(\,h(x)\,)\, ) \\ \hline \sin x & \tan^{-1} x & e^{-x} & f(\,g(e^{-x})\,)\\ & & & = f(\,\tan^{-1} (e^{-x} )\,) \\ & & & = \sin(\,\tan^{-1} (e^{-x})\,) \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ f(\,g(\,h(x)\,)\,)\textbf{ is normally written as }(f\circ g\circ h)(x). \\ \textbf{And just for fun }\\ \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline (g\circ f\circ h)(x) & \tan^{-1}(\sin(e^{-x})) \\ \hline (h\circ g\circ f)(x) & e^{-\tan^{-1}(\sin x)} \\ \hline (h\circ f\circ g)(x) & e^{-\sin (\tan^{-1} x)} \\ \hline \end{tabular}

\text{If }y = f(\, g(x)\,) = (f\circ g)(x),\text{ then }\\ \quad \underbrace{\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{d}{d g(x)}f(\, g(x)\,)\cdot\frac{d}{dx}g(x)}_{\textbf{Chain Rule}} \\ \textbf{In this question, however, } y = f(\, g(\, h(x)\, )\,). \\ \text{Hence, the expression for }\frac{dy}{dx}\text{ is a little longer.}\\ \text{But the idea is the same.}
